intro: Asperula gobicola, commonly known as the desert azalea, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant is adapted to harsh environments, featuring small, leathery leaves that reduce water loss. It produces pink or white blooms in the spring, adding a splash of color to its rocky habitat. Asperula gobicola is often found growing in dry slopes and gravelly soils, showcasing its resilience to extreme conditions.
